chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Acute pilonidal abscess
chapter.summary: Covers the primary care management and referral of acute pilonidal abscess.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 16 years onwards.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage acute pilonidal abscess?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• If a person presents with an acute pilonidal abscess:
    • Arrange for an urgent same-day incision and drainage.
      • Incision and drainage may sometimes be performed in primary care if the lesion is small and superficial, and the expertise and facilities are available. Otherwise, the person should be referred to a colorectal or general surgical unit according to local protocol.
    • Offer paracetamol for pain and/or fever. 
      • If the response is insufficient, also offer a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID), such as ibuprofen or naproxen (unless not tolerated or contraindicated).
      • See the CKS topics on Analgesia - mild-to-moderate pain and NSAIDs - prescribing issues for prescribing information.
    • If there is associated cellulitis, consider prescribing antibiotic treatment.
      • See the CKS topic on Cellulitis - acute for more information.
  • Following surgical incision and drainage:
    • Advise the person on long-term measures that may reduce the risk of recurrence, including:
      • Meticulous perianal hygiene with regular baths or showers.
      • Buttock hair removal techniques, such as laser treatment, waxing, shaving, and depilatory creams (there is some evidence of a lower recurrence rate after laser hair removal compared with shaving and depilatory creams).
    • Provide patient information on pilonidal sinus disease. For example:
      • Pilonidal sinus published by NHS (www.nhs.uk).

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are based largely on The treatment of pilonidal disease: guidelines of the Italian Society of Colorectal Surgery (SICCR) [Segre, 2015], the German national guideline on the management of pilonidal disease [Iesalnieks, 2016], The American Society of Colon and Rectal Surgeons’ Clinical Practice Guidelines for the Management of Pilonidal Disease [Johnson, 2019], evidence from two systematcc reviews [Halleran, 2018; Pronk, 2018] and a prospective case control study [Harlak, 2010], and on expert opinion in review articles on pilonidal sinus [Marza, 2013; BMJ, 2018; Kober, 2018; Choy, 2019].

Arranging same-day incision and drainage
  • Experts agree that a pilonidal abscess should be incised and drained [Segre, 2015; Iesalnieks, 2016; BMJ, 2018; Kober, 2018; Choy, 2019; Johnson, 2019] to decrease pain and relieve tension [Kober, 2018]. Expert opinion in a review article is that localized source control is the mainstay of treatment for an acute pilonidal abscess. This includes needle aspiration, drainage without curettage of the cavity, and primary drainage and curettage of the cavity to remove any hair follicles or debrisis [Choy, 2019].
  • Evidence suggests that more than 50–60% of people presenting for the first time with an acute abscess healed completely after simple incision and drainage [Thompson et al, 2011; Johnson, 2019].
Offering analgesia
  • This recommendation is pragmatic and is based on what CKS considers to be good medical practice. In addition, expert opinion in two nursing review articles recommends offering analgesia to people with active pilonidal sinus disease [Timmons, 2007; Marza, 2013].
Long-term hygiene measures to reduce the risk of recurrence
  • A prospective case control study that included 587 people with pilonidal sinus disease and 2780 healthy controls found that the risk of pilonidal sinus disease was higher in people who take two or less showers or baths per week compared with those who take three or more baths per week [Harlak, 2010].
  • Expert opinion in a nursing review article is that people who have fewer than two baths a week are more at risk of developing pilonidal sinus disease, presumably due to the increased risk of bacterial proliferation in the natal cleft region [Marza, 2013].
Long-term hair removal measures to reduce the risk of recurrence
  • The rationale to support removal of hair in the natal cleft relates to the significance of cleft hair in the pathophysiology of pilonidal sinus disease, although it is unclear whether the development of pilonidal sinus disease is secondary to local pressure on the tissues, ruptured hair follicles, hypoxic tissue beds, or a congenital vulnerability of the natal skin [Johnson, 2019]. 
  • Any method of hair removal can be used. However, current available evidence supports the use of laser treatment as a primary or adjuvant treatment of pilonidal sinus disease, although large randomized controlled trials are needed to confirm these findings [Halleran, 2018; Kober, 2018; Pronk, 2018; Choy, 2019].
    • A systematic review assessed the published literature on laser hair depilation in pilonidal disease to determine its effect on disease recurrence [Halleran, 2018].
      • Thirty-five published studies were included, and the number of participants included in each study ranged from 1–86.
      • The pilonidal sinus disease recurrence rate after laser depilation ranged from 0–28% at a mean follow up ranging from 6 months to 5 years across studies. Four of the five studies that included a comparative group demonstrated a decreased recurrence rate compared with the non-laser cohort.
    • A second systematic review assessed the literature regarding the effect of hair depilation on the recurrence rate in people surgically treated for sacrococcygeal pilonidal sinus disease [Pronk, 2018].
      • Fourteen studies (n = 963) were included. The mean length of follow up was 37 months.
      • The recurrence rate was 9.3% (34 out of 366) in those who had laser hair removal, 23.4% (36 out of 154) in those who had razor shaving/cream depilation, and 19.7% (85 out of 431) in those who had no hair removal after surgery for sacrococcygeal pilonidal sinus disease.
      • The systematic review showed a lower recurrence rate after laser hair removal compared with no hair removal and razor/cream depilation.
Providing patient information
  • The recommendation to provide patient information on pilonidal sinus disease is based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice.
